Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Connection Between Tropical Cyclones and Climate Through Multi-Model Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objectives of this project are as follows (i) to improve the understanding of natural variability and trends in tropical cyclone (TC) activity since the beginning of the 20th century; (ii) to quantify projected changes in the characteristics of tropical cyclones under a warming climate. The multi-model dataset generated by the recently established U.S. Climate Predictability and Variability program working group on hurricanes and climate, will be analyzed. The common set of diagnostics will include cyclone tracks and intensities, analysis of key tropical TC statistics, analysis of environmental conditions associated with TC genesis and intensification in the models.

The work aims at better understanding of the relationship between TC in the present, as well as more robust and quantitative projects of TC activity in the future, based on the analysis of a unique high-resolution multi-model dataset. This data set will advance the understanding of the relationship between climate and TC; in addition international and national collaboration will be enhances as a result of interactions between several modeling groups. It will promote training through mentoring of post-doctoral scientists as well through outreach activities in the New York area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical cyclones, also called hurricanes or typhoons, can have significant social and economical impacts. Therefore, it is important to have a better understanding how climate variability and change can influence tropical cyclone activity globally.  With the improvement of computers and climate models, it is now possible to simulate many characteristics of tropical cyclones using climate models.  However, climate models from different modeling groups have very different ability in reproducing tropical cyclone climatology characteristics and that can influence how well they respond to climate variability and change. As usually different modeling groups use different forcing in their simulations, it is very hard to know if the differences among the models are mostly due to different forcing or different model characteristics.

Because of that, the US Climate Variability and Predictability Program (CLIVAR) created the Hurricane Working Group, which lasted from 2011 to 2014.  The main objective of this Working Group was to improve the understanding of interannual variability and trends in tropical cyclone activity from the beginning of the 20th century to the present and quantify changes in the characteristics of tropical cyclones under a warming climate.  Various modeling groups around the world contributed to this effort, performing specific idealized simulations of current and future climate with high-resolution climate models.

This NSF project used the availability of this unique multi-model dataset to analyze various aspects of the tropical cyclone activity. One important aspect of this dataset is that all modeling groups performed exactly the same simulations, with the same forcing, which allows an even comparison among the models, which is not possible in other settings. Our analysis made clear that just increasing model resolution does not necessarily leads to improved tropical cyclone simulation in climate models.  Models with the same (or very similar) resolution have tropical cyclone climatology that differ in their most basic characteristics, for instance the mean number of tropical cyclones globally and in different regions. Overall, the observed geographic distribution of global tropical cyclone frequency was reasonably well reproduced. Furthermore, although the maximum intensity that these storms can reach is restricted by the model resolution, there is a clear difference among models of same resolution as well, pointing towards differences in model parametrizations, i.e. how models describe some processes that are not resolved by the models. In particular, convection schemes, how model represent clouds, have an important influence on the distribution of the tropical cyclones intensity in different models.

Different modeling groups usually have different algorithms to detect and track tropical cyclones in the climate model output. Although in principle these tracking algorithms are very similar, they can lead to different number of storms in the climate models. Applying different tracking schemes to the same model output we showed that these differences are more acute for weak storms and tend to become less important as model resolution increases.

Simulating realistic tropical cyclone tracks is another important issue, as the landfalling storms, which are the ones that have societal impact, depend on their tracks. We compared the model tropical cyclones tracks in various regions with the observed tracks, as well as synthetic tracks generated using the model environmental fields. In the North Atlantic, the synthetic tracks are better able to capture the observed characteristics of the tracks, with the exception of seasonality. Furthermore, the response of tracks changes to different warming scenarios is highly dependable on the model and idealized simulation considered, with no clear robust change across models and scenarios.

The response of North Atlantic and Western North Pacific tropical cyclone activity to different phases of the El Niño – Southern Oscillation (ENSO) was also analyzed. Overall the models are able to reproduce some aspects of the ENSO response, for instance the modulation in frequency in the North Atlantic basin according to the ENSO phase. However, the spatial distribution of the North Atlantic response is not as well simulated due to models biases in their response to the shifts in tropical heating.  In the western North Pacific, while most models can reproduce the interannual variability due to ENSO, they cannot distinguish between the differences in the two flavors of El Niño (central and eastern Pacific).

In summary, while significant progress has been made in simulating tropical cyclones in climate models, there are still many issues that need to be addressed. While some aspects of the TC responses to climate variability and change are well done, others are either different from the observations, or not robust across models.  Therefore, it is fundamental to support further improvement in high-resolution climate models simulations of tropical cyclones. We had the opportunity to present our results to the public, to the media, as well as to the academic community in various settings throughout the period of this grant.
